articles.headline: After Bust in Ireland, Ordinary People Make Do With Less
articles.snippet: Many people in Ireland who floated up during the good times now see themselves slipping even further behind.
articles.abstract: Many people in Ireland who floated up during the good times now see themselves slipping even further behind.
articles.lead_paragraph: DROGHEDA, Ireland — Brian and Rosie Condra grew up poor. But as prosperity washed over Ireland in the first decade of the 21st century, they managed to buy a modest house, start saving for their children’s future and, for once, do more than simply make ends meet.

articles.headline: ID Theft Tool That Sony Isn’t Using
articles.snippet: A credit report monitoring service will alert you only after the damage is done. Instituting a credit freeze will prevent anyone from opening an account in your name.
articles.abstract: A credit report monitoring service will alert you only after the damage is done. Instituting a credit freeze will prevent anyone from opening an account in your name.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Sony’s chairman and chief executive, Howard Stringer, finally got around to apologizing for the security breach that left the personal data of 77 million customers vulnerable to hackers.

articles.headline: Ministers Meet to Study Fixes on Greek Debt
articles.snippet: European finance ministers met to discuss new moves to prevent the huge burden of Greek debt from overwhelming the country’s economy.
articles.abstract: European finance ministers met to discuss new moves to prevent the huge burden of Greek debt from overwhelming the country’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: New moves to prevent the huge burden of Greek debt from overwhelming the country’s economy were discussed Friday during an unannounced meeting of a small group of European finance ministers, including those from Germany, France and Greece.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: A Titan Under a Microscope
articles.snippet: Steven A. Cohen, the founder of SAC Capital Advisors, has never been charged with illegal trading, but two managers and some former traders at the firm have.
articles.abstract: Steven A. Cohen, the founder of SAC Capital Advisors, has never been charged with illegal trading, but two managers and some former traders at the firm have.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen, the once-secretive billionaire hedge fund manager, is suddenly everywhere.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Trying to Game Google on ‘Mother’s Day Flowers’
articles.snippet: Experts say that Teleflora, FTD, 1800Flowers.com and ProFlowers are violating guidelines in their quest to rise in online search results.
articles.abstract: Experts say that Teleflora, FTD, 1800Flowers.com and ProFlowers are violating guidelines in their quest to rise in online search results.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mother’s Day flowers.

articles.headline: With Death Outpacing Birth, a County Slows to a Shuffle
articles.snippet: With just 71 babies born on average for every 100 deaths, Brooke County, in West Virginia, has the largest such gap in the nation among counties in metropolitan areas.
articles.abstract: With just 71 babies born on average for every 100 deaths, Brooke County, in West Virginia, has the largest such gap in the nation among counties in metropolitan areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEIRTON, W. Va. — Life in this industrial area has slowed to a shuffle along with the steel mills that used to power it. Young people have moved away, leaving an aging population that no longer has the energy to put on street fairs or holiday parades.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Face That Screamed War’s Pain Looks Back, 6 Hard Years Later
articles.snippet: Photographs of Samar Hassan at five years old, screaming and splattered in blood, illuminated the horror of civilian casualties in Iraq.
articles.abstract: Photographs of Samar Hassan at five years old, screaming and splattered in blood, illuminated the horror of civilian casualties in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSUL, Iraq — Until the past week, Samar Hassan had never glimpsed the photograph of her that millions had seen, never knew it had become one of the most famous images of the Iraq war.

articles.headline: Moving the Goal Posts on Pay
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart’s change in a measuring stick for executive compensation has interesting timing.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart’s change in a measuring stick for executive compensation has interesting timing.
articles.lead_paragraph: PEOPLE scrutinize just about everything Wal-Mart does. As Michael T. Duke, the company’s chief executive, put it recently, “What we do and how we perform is watched closely not only by our customers and shareholders, but also by the whole world.”

articles.headline: The Prince of Lord & Taylor
articles.snippet: Anyone who thought Richard A. Baker was getting in over his head when he bought Lord & Taylor and the Hudson’s Bay Company must be reconsidering.
articles.abstract: Anyone who thought Richard A. Baker was getting in over his head when he bought Lord & Taylor and the Hudson’s Bay Company must be reconsidering.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCARSDALE, N.Y.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: The Class That Built Apps, and Fortunes
articles.snippet: In 2007, the “Facebook Class” at Stanford created free apps for millions of users. But it also fired up the careers of many students and pioneered a new model of entrepreneurship.
articles.abstract: In 2007, the “Facebook Class” at Stanford created free apps for millions of users. But it also fired up the careers of many students and pioneered a new model of entrepreneurship.
articles.lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif.

articles.headline: Bin Laden’s Secret Life in a Diminished World
articles.snippet: While Bin Laden’s world had shrunk, he was still revered at home — by his wives, his children and a tight circle of loyalists.
articles.abstract: While Bin Laden’s world had shrunk, he was still revered at home — by his wives, his children and a tight circle of loyalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The world’s most wanted terrorist lived his last five years imprisoned behind the barbed wire and high walls of his home in Abbottabad, Pakistan, his days consumed by dark arts and domesticity.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller, Carlotta Gall and Salman Masood

articles.headline: In China, Fear of Fake Eggs and ‘Recycled’ Buns
articles.snippet: A stomach-turning string of food-safety scandals this spring, from recycled buns to contaminated pork, makes it clear that official efforts are falling short.
articles.abstract: A stomach-turning string of food-safety scandals this spring, from recycled buns to contaminated pork, makes it clear that official efforts are falling short.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — On a bustling corner near downtown Shanghai recently, some shoppers avoided the steamed buns sold by Zhu Qinghe in a street-side cubbyhole. Instead, they bought the packaged buns in the freezer section of Hualian, a supermarket chain store in the same building.

articles.headline: Big G.O.P. Donors Adopt Wait-and-See 2012 Tack
articles.snippet: The vaunted Republican network of high-dollar donors and fund-raisers has been slow to commit itself, resulting in a faltering start to the party’s drive to unseat President Obama.
articles.abstract: The vaunted Republican network of high-dollar donors and fund-raisers has been slow to commit itself, resulting in a faltering start to the party’s drive to unseat President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: The vaunted Republican network of high-dollar donors and fund-raisers, for so long a fear factor for Democrats, has been slow to commit itself to the 2012 presidential candidates, contributing to the faltering start of the party’s drive to unseat President Obama.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Nuclear Agency Is Criticized as Too Close to Its Industry
articles.snippet: Critics have long painted the Nuclear Regulatory Commission as well-intentioned but weak.
articles.abstract: Critics have long painted the Nuclear Regulatory Commission as well-intentioned but weak.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2007, workers at the Byron nuclear power plant in Illinois were using a wire brush to clean a badly corroded steel pipe — one in a series that circulate cooling water to essential emergency equipment — when something unexpected happened: the brush poked through.

articles.headline: Now, to Find a Parking Spot, Drivers Look on Their Phones
articles.snippet: In San Francisco, a phone app gives information about areas with available parking spaces.
articles.abstract: In San Francisco, a phone app gives information about areas with available parking spaces.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is the urban driver’s most agonizing everyday experience: the search for an empty parking place.

articles.headline: Syria Broadens Deadly Crackdown on Protesters
articles.snippet: The crackdown seemed to mark a decisive turn in an uprising that has posed a grave challenge to President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.abstract: The crackdown seemed to mark a decisive turn in an uprising that has posed a grave challenge to President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A military crackdown on Syria’s seven-week uprising escalated Sunday, with reinforcements sent to two cities, more forces deployed in a southern town and nearly all communications severed to besieged locales, activists and human rights groups said. Fourteen people were killed in the city of Homs, they said, and hundreds were arrested.

articles.headline: U.S. Raises Pressure on Pakistan in Raid’s Wake
articles.snippet: The U.S. government wants to control the investigation to determine whether Pakistani government, intelligence or military officials were complicit in hiding Osama bin Laden.
articles.abstract: The U.S. government wants to control the investigation to determine whether Pakistani government, intelligence or military officials were complicit in hiding Osama bin Laden.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s national security adviser demanded Sunday that Pakistan let American investigators interview Osama bin Laden’s three widows, adding new pressure in a relationship now fraught over how Bin Laden could have been hiding near Islamabad for years before he was killed by commandos last week.

articles.headline: AOL’s Leader Undaunted in Overhaul Efforts
articles.snippet: Tim Armstrong says he has not lost faith that his overhaul of the company will reverse its decline.
articles.abstract: Tim Armstrong says he has not lost faith that his overhaul of the company will reverse its decline.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Tim Armstrong, AOL’s chief executive, will tell just about anyone who will listen that AOL is not some washed-up tech company from another era.

articles.headline: Now to Sell Advertisers on Tablets
articles.snippet: Magazine publishers are making plans to be part of, rather than run over by, the digital revolution.
articles.abstract: Magazine publishers are making plans to be part of, rather than run over by, the digital revolution.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you wanted to get your message in front of a reader of The New Yorker, it would cost you $141,174 for a full-page ad in the magazine’s glossy pages.

articles.headline: Response to Volatility in Silver Takes Hold
articles.snippet: Worried about the soaring prices of commodities, exchange officials are raising the collateral needed to guarantee trades.
articles.abstract: Worried about the soaring prices of commodities, exchange officials are raising the collateral needed to guarantee trades.
articles.lead_paragraph: On April 25, half a dozen officials from the CME Group, which runs many of the nation’s commodities exchanges, met via videophone to discuss the eye-popping rise in the price of silver, which had doubled in just six months to about $47 a troy ounce.
articles.byline: By William Neuman and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: Suit Opens a Window Into Google
articles.snippet: E-mails disclosed by a state court illuminate strategy as Google protects its Android software for smartphones.
articles.abstract: E-mails disclosed by a state court illuminate strategy as Google protects its Android software for smartphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: A stack of internal e-mail messages from Google, which a Massachusetts state court made public last week, provide a glimpse into the competitive tactics and decision-making inside a business that is crucial to the company’s growth — its Android software for smartphones.

articles.headline: Mexico Takes Aim at a Titan in Telecom
articles.snippet: Recent moves by Mexican authorities threaten to chip away at the dominance of Carlos Slim’s empire.
articles.abstract: Recent moves by Mexican authorities threaten to chip away at the dominance of Carlos Slim’s empire.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In the two decades that Carlos Slim Helú has turned a crumbling Mexican phone monopoly into a continental telecom giant, he has successfully fought off competitors and challenged authorities who wanted to limit his companies’ control.

articles.headline: In Cable Niches, Less Reality and More Original Shows
articles.snippet: To stay competitive, relatively small cable channels that once relied on reality shows and repeats of others’ scripted programs are now showing original comedies and dramas.
articles.abstract: To stay competitive, relatively small cable channels that once relied on reality shows and repeats of others’ scripted programs are now showing original comedies and dramas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stacy Littlejohn worked her way up in network television like so many other writers and producers — she was a writers’ assistant on a Fox show, a joke writer on a CW show, a writer-producer on a half-hour ABC show.

articles.headline: Seeking Business, States Loosen Insurance Rules
articles.snippet: To lure business, some states are offering a refuge from rules, especially those requiring companies to set aside enough money to pay future claims.
articles.abstract: To lure business, some states are offering a refuge from rules, especially those requiring companies to set aside enough money to pay future claims.
articles.lead_paragraph: Companies looking to do business in secret once had to travel to places like the Cayman Islands or Bermuda.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Louise Story

articles.headline: Smugglers Guide Illegal Immigrants With Cues via Cellphone
articles.snippet: Some smugglers are keeping track of border patrols from afar and then texting advice to immigrants coming into the United States.
articles.abstract: Some smugglers are keeping track of border patrols from afar and then texting advice to immigrants coming into the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOGALES, Ariz. — A group of migrants was hustling north through the southern Arizona desert the other night when one of their cellphones vibrated with a text message. “Watch out,” it warned. “Things are hot up ahead. Take cover in the bushes.”

articles.headline: Syria Proclaims It Now Has Upper Hand Over Uprising
articles.snippet: A senior official gave a clear sign that the leadership believes it will crush protests that have faltered after mass arrests and hundreds of deaths.
articles.abstract: A senior official gave a clear sign that the leadership believes it will crush protests that have faltered after mass arrests and hundreds of deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — The Syrian government has gained the upper hand over a seven-week uprising against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad, a senior official declared Monday, in the clearest sign yet that the leadership believes its crackdown will crush protests that have begun to falter in the face of hundreds of deaths and mass arrests.
